headline: In Ohio's redistricting battle, Gov. Mike DeWine said he'd take the lead. But did he?
author: Jessie Balmert
sentences: "I believed that the best way – the best shot that we had at getting a 10-year map and getting a nonpartisan map was to let the Democrats come forward with a proposal and the Republicans come forward with a proposal and then see where everybody was and then be a person that could try and pull this together," DeWine said.

DeWine can't control the commission
In legal filings attempting to fend off the threat of contempt of court, DeWine argues that he can't be held responsible for the actions – or lack thereof – of fellow commission members.

The commission includes three statewide officials – DeWine, Ohio Auditor Keith Faber and Ohio Secretary of State Frank LaRose, all Republicans – in addition to four legislative leaders, two Republicans and two Democrats.

But the GOP supermajority hasn't been kind to some of DeWine's policies, overriding the governor's veto on health orders and stymying efforts to increase penalties on texting while driving or reform police training.
